name: Round with Bead Ladders
notes: Bundle golden beads into tens and hundreds, then decide which benchmark the number is nearest to.

name: Mental Rounding Strategies
notes: Use hundred-board highlight strips to practice rounding without manipulatives before recording equations.

name: Rounding on Open Number Lines
notes: Place numbers on an open line, mark benchmarks, and justify rounding choices aloud.

name: Rounding in Context
notes: Model real-world problems that require rounding and record the reasoning with bar models.

name: Estimation Strategy Workshop
notes: Compare rounding, front-end, and number-line jumps to decide which estimation strategy is most efficient.

name: Estimate in Real-World Contexts
notes: Use bar models to plan estimates for multi-step scenarios, then check reasonableness against exact answers.

name: Checkerboard Addition within 1,000
notes: Use the checkerboard or stamp game to add multiple three-digit numbers with regrouping.

name: Addition Strategy Journal
notes: Record and critique different addition strategies for the same three-digit problems.

name: Three-Digit Subtraction Exchanges
notes: Model regrouping across hundreds, tens, and ones while subtracting within 1,000.

name: Subtraction Contexts within 1,000
notes: Use bar models and recorded equations to solve multi-step subtraction problems within 1,000.

name: Analyze Place-Value Situations
notes: Interpret place-value puzzles with bar models and justify the strategy used.

name: Multi-Step Place-Value Challenges
notes: Tackle multi-step problems that intertwine comparisons, rounding, and operations on three-digit numbers.

name: Analyze Equal-Group Stories
notes: Represent equal-group stories with bar models and determine when multiplication applies.

name: Equal Groups and Division
notes: Decide whether to divide to find group size or number of groups and justify the choice.

name: Plan Two-Step Solutions
notes: Sequence operations for two-step contexts and record each equation clearly.

name: Check Two-Step Answers
notes: Use inverse operations and estimation to verify two-step solutions.

name: Division Grouping Mats
notes: Arrange bead bars into equal groups and express the action as a division equation.

name: Repeated Subtraction on Number Lines
notes: Translate equal groups into repeated subtraction jumps on an open number line.

name: Share Sets Equally
notes: Share counters equally, record the division equation, and relate it to the inverse multiplication fact.

name: Related Multiplication and Division Facts
notes: Use area models and bead arrays to highlight how multiplication and division facts are connected.

name: Division Story Analysis
notes: Decode division scenarios, build models, and solve for unknown group size or number of groups.

name: Explain Division Solutions
notes: Construct written explanations that justify the chosen operation and interpretation of the quotient.

name: Multiplication Strategy Lab
notes: Apply commutative and doubling strategies to tough facts using bead stair representations.

name: Area Strategies for Facts
notes: Create area models to visualize multiplication facts and explore identity/zero cases.

name: Distributive & Associative Reasoning
notes: Cut and rearrange arrays to justify distributive and associative strategies for large facts.

name: Apply Multiplication/Division Fact Families
notes: Build triangle-board families and apply them to real-life multiplicative situations.

name: Advanced Division Fact Strategies
notes: Compare strategies for dividing within 100 and reflect on which method fits different fact families.

name: Mixed Fact Challenge Studio
notes: Rotate through timed practice, strategy reflection, and story problems to solidify fact fluency.

name: Partial Products with Arrays
notes: Split arrays into partial products to compute multiplication within 100.

name: Unknown Factors and Quotients
notes: Use inverse reasoning to find missing factors or quotients from array and area models.

name: Factor Tracks Skip Counting
notes: Lay factor tracks on an open number line to solidify skip-counting sequences.

name: Complete Skip-Counting Patterns
notes: Fill in missing multiples on the hundred board and explain the pattern.

name: Skip Counting Word Problems
notes: Apply skip-counting to solve multiplicative comparison and equal-group contexts.

name: Multiply by Multiples of Ten
notes: Use place-value cards and bead bars to multiply single-digit numbers by multiples of ten.

name: Input-Output Machine Patterns
notes: Program function machines and hundred-chart tables to identify arithmetic patterns.

name: Generalize Arithmetic Rules
notes: Explain how multiplication properties create patterns across rows and columns.

name: Balance Equations with Unknowns
notes: Use the balance scale to solve for unknowns represented by letters.

name: Graph and Interpret Inequalities
notes: Plot inequality solutions on a number line and explain the meaning in context.

name: Partition Shape Mosaics
notes: Partition polygons into equal shares and verify equality by overlaying fraction insets.

name: Name Unit Fractions
notes: Label shaded regions with correct unit fraction names and explain the numerator/denominator roles.

name: Build Fraction Number Lines
notes: Partition bead-linked number lines into equal jumps and label each unit fraction.

name: Compare Fractions on Number Lines
notes: Place non-unit fractions and show how whole numbers align with fractional equivalents.

name: Fractions of Sets Lab
notes: Share skittles into equal groups to compute fractions of sets and record supporting equations.

name: Interpret Fractions as Division
notes: Connect fractional set problems to division expressions and explain the quotient meaning.

name: Compare Fractions with Insets
notes: Overlay fraction insets to reason about the size of different unit fractions.

name: Compare Fractions with Same Numerators or Denominators
notes: Plot fractions on a number line to justify comparisons with like numerators or denominators.

name: Equivalent Fractions with Area Models
notes: Shade equivalent regions to demonstrate how fractions can represent the same amount.

name: Generate Equivalent Fractions Strategically
notes: Scale numerators and denominators to generate equivalent fractions and position them on aligned number lines.

name: Triangle Classification Box
notes: Sort triangles by side and angle properties using constructive triangles.

name: Quadrilateral Hierarchy
notes: Organize quadrilaterals by properties and discuss relationships among categories.

name: Tile Lab for Area
notes: Cover rectangles with unit squares and connect the area to multiplication equations.

name: Rectilinear Area Designs
notes: Break complex floor plans into rectangles and right triangles to compute total area.

name: Perimeter Exploration
notes: Measure polygon sides with digital strips and apply perimeter formulas.

name: Fraction Line Plot Project
notes: Collect fractional measurement data and plot it on a line graph with halves and fourths.

name: Interpret Fraction Line Plots
notes: Solve comparison and difference questions based on fractional line plots.

name: Compare Object Masses
notes: Measure and compare masses using gram weights and record differences.

name: Mix and Measure Volume
notes: Combine and compare liquid volumes using Montessori pitchers and graduated cylinders.

name: Mass and Volume Problem Solving
notes: Use bar models to tackle multi-step scenarios involving mass and liquid volume.

name: Scaled Graph Project
notes: Collect data, choose a scale, build the bar graph, and answer comparison questions.

name: Interpret Multiple Data Representations
notes: Select the best graph for a situation and solve associated word problems.

name: Elapsed Time Timeline
notes: Use clock faces and timelines to compute elapsed time to the nearest minute.

name: Start and End Time Challenges
notes: Find missing start or end times for events spanning up to several hours.

name: Time and Money Multi-Step Problems
notes: Blend elapsed time and coin counting within multi-step bar-model scenarios.

name: Multi-Step Case Studies
notes: Analyze rich problems, plan sequences of operations, and justify each step.
